content: Ilayda Dinc is a 2nd year masters student at the University of California Santa Barbara Bren School of Environmental Science and Management. She is focusing on Strategic Environmental Communication and Media. Her master's thesis projects aims to assess the impact of regenerative organic agriculture.
summary: Ilayda Dinc is a 2nd year masters student at the University of California Santa Barbara Bren School of Environmental Science and Management. She is focusing on Strategic Environmental Communication and Media. Her master's thesis projects aims to assess the impact of regenerative organic agriculture.
title: Ilayda Dinc

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

summary: Assessing the Impacts of Regenerative Organic Agriculture
title: Carbon for Crops Master's Thesis Project

content:
The study aims to understand the changes in Snowshoe hare(Lepus americanus) density and physical characteristics of Snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest in Alaska between years 1998-2012. Capture-recapture studies of snowshoe hares at 5 different locations showed that snowshoe hare densities has been declining since 1999[1]. This project analyzes the survival of snowshow hares by looking at the changes in physical characteristics of Snowshoe hares over time.
 Figure 1: Snowshoe Hare (Lepus Americanus) in the season change. Snowshoe hares are covered with white fur over winter and their fur starts to turn brown as the snow fades. Source: http://timberjay.com/stories/for-snowshoe-hares-its-time-for-a-change,14060
  #Read in the data #Do some cleanup snowshoe<- read_csv("showshoe_lter.csv") %>% mutate(date=mdy(date)) %>% separate(date, into = c("year","month","day"), sep = "-")%>% mutate(grid= str_to_lower(grid), age=str_to_lower(age), sex=str_to_lower(sex)) %>% select(-time,-notes) snowshoe2<- snowshoe %>% mutate(body_condition= weight/hindft) # add a column for the body condition index # summary(snowshoe2) summary_snowshoe<- snowshoe2 %>% group_by(year) %>% summarize( avg_mass = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), avg_length= mean(hindft,na.rm = TRUE), avg_body= mean(body_condition,na.rm = TRUE), sd= sd(body_condition,na.rm= TRUE), sample =length(year)) # mutate columns for average stats: average weight, average hindfeet length and average body condition index and the standard deviation of average body condition index #Create the data frame for the summary statistics table table2<- summary_snowshoe%>% mutate(`Mean Weight (g) ` = round(avg_mass, 2), `Mean Hindfeet Length (mm)` = round(avg_length, 2), 'Mean Body Condition Index (g/mm)'= round(avg_body,2)) %>% rename("Year" = year, "Sample Size"= sample) %>% drop_na() %>% select(-avg_mass,-avg_length,-avg_body,-sd) #Clean up the names and get rid of deselect unused columns snowshoe_graph_2 <- ggplot(summary_snowshoe, aes(x = year, y = avg_body)) + geom_bar(stat="identity", color="black",fill= "darkseagreen", position=position_dodge())+ geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=avg_body-sd, ymax=avg_body+sd), width=.2, position=position_dodge())+ theme_bw() + labs(x = "Year", y = "Body Condition Index (g/mm)")+ scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0,24, by = 2))+ theme(text = element_text(size=14))+ theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, vjust = 1)) snowshoe_graph_2 Figure 2: Snowshoe Hare Body Condition over the years (1998-2012). Body Weight/ Hindfoot Length is used as the Body Condition Index based on the previous research stating that body condition is strongly correlated to mass and hind foot length, and the index is robust to age and sex differences [2] The bars represent the yearly mean Body Condition Indices of both adult and juvenile snowshoe hares from both sex. Error bars indicate ± 1 standard deviation. The Body Condition Indices showed an overall decreasing trend over the years. The error bars show that variance of Body Condition Indices within the population are getting smaller. Data used with permission from The Bonanza Creek LTER.
Over the years, snowshow hare population density has been decreasing. Studies has been conducted to see if this is related to the physical conditions of snowshow hares. The graph in Figure 2 shows there is a general decreasing trend in the body conditions of snowshow hares in Bonanza Creek. Also, there is less variance in the body conditions withing the survivor population.
kable(table2, caption = '<b>Body conditions of Snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek between 1998 and 2012.</b> The table summarizes the information about body condition metrics over the years. Sample size represents the number of catch-recatches. Information about mean weight and mean hindfeet length are presented, and mean body condition index ( mean of (weight / hindfeet length) ratios) is calculated to account for the age and sex differences. <i>Data used with permission from The Bonanza Creek LTER.<i> ') %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped","responsive", "hold_position", "hover","condensed","bordered"), full_width = FALSE, position = "center")  Table 1: Body conditions of Snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek between 1998 and 2012. The table summarizes the information about body condition metrics over the years. Sample size represents the number of catch-recatches. Information about mean weight and mean hindfeet length are presented, and mean body condition index ( mean of (weight / hindfeet length) ratios) is calculated to account for the age and sex differences. Data used with permission from The Bonanza Creek LTER.     Year  Sample Size  Mean Weight (g)  Mean Hindfeet Length (mm)  Mean Body Condition Index (g/mm)      1998  60  1704.75  125.57  13.30    1999  392  1250.38  130.82  9.88    2000  260  1376.64  131.66  11.32    2001  102  1390.21  133.79  11.04    2002  38  1201.57  124.72  9.24    2003  59  1212.72  127.56  9.36    2004  97  1472.16  131.78  11.05    2005  174  1269.00  124.30  9.43    2006  193  1364.58  126.07  9.72    2007  203  1371.70  127.79  10.04    2008  351  1317.25  127.45  9.44    2009  491  1337.73  134.60  9.58    2010  402  1392.84  134.00  9.72    2011  427  1403.96  133.75  9.83    2012  131  1327.38  137.60  9.53     REFERENCES
[1] :Kielland, Knut; Chapin, F. Stuart; Ruess, Roger W. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present, Bonanza Creek LTER - University of Alaska Fairbanks. BNZ:55, http://www.lter.uaf.edu/data/data-detail/id/55. doi:10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14
[2] Wirsing Aaron J, Steury Todd D, Murray Dennis L. Noninvasive estimation of body composition in small mammals: a comparison of conductive and morphometric techniques. Physiol Biochem Zool. 2002;75(5):489–97
summary: This project visualizes the changes in the body condition of Snowshow hares over the years.
title: Data Wrangling and Visualization

content:
NUTRITIONAL INFORMATION OF CHEESE   Part 1 U.S. Department of Agriculture compiles the nutritional information of various of foods groups such as dairy and egg products, spices and herbs, fats and oils and etc through the integrated data system FoodData Central. The data includes total energy content(kcal) as well as the amount of nutrients and vitamins. I’ll be exploring dairy and egg products and focusing on cheese, because I love cheese. If you do too, keep reading and find out about this how different nutritional information are correlated and how the variance in this information can be expressed as much as possible.
Data Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture , Agricultural Research Service. FoodData Central, 2019. fdc.nal.usda.gov.
 Part 2 #Read in the data #Do some cleanup nutrient <- read_csv("usda_nutrients.csv") %>% clean_names() %>% mutate( food_group = str_to_lower(food_group)) # Explore the data summary(nutrient) names(nutrient) #gg_miss_var(nutrient) #name columns have a lot of missing variables #Getting just the cheese #getting rid of name columns nutrient_cheese <-nutrient %>% filter(food_group=="dairy and egg products") %>% select(-common_name, - mfg_name, -scientific_name) %>% mutate( descrip = str_to_lower(descrip) )%>% filter(str_detect(descrip, pattern = "cheese")) #making the subset for the PCA with energy content, all the nutrients and vitamins cheese_subset <- nutrient_cheese %>% select(energy_kcal:zinc_usrda) # Trying prcomp function my_cheese_pca <- prcomp(cheese_subset, scale = TRUE) my_cheese_pca #looking at na situation #summary(cheese_subset) #double checking for the missing variables #gg_miss_var(cheese_subset) #no na #matrixplot(cheese_subset) #no red #plotting my pca #plot(my_cheese_pca) #summary(my_cheese_pca) # cumulative proportion for 2 dimensions is 44% #biplot(my_cheese_pca) #messy #trying autopilot my_biplot <- autoplot(my_cheese_pca, colour = NA, loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.label.size = 3, loadings.label.colour = "black", loadings.label.repel = TRUE) + theme_minimal() my_biplot # looks better #let's just look at the macro nutrients # Fix the column names my_sub2 <- cheese_subset %>% select(energy_kcal, protein_g, fat_g,carb_g,sugar_g,fiber_g) %>% rename("Energy Content (kcal)" = energy_kcal, "Protein (g)"= protein_g, "Fat (g)"= fat_g, "Sugar (g)"= sugar_g,"Fiber (g)"=fiber_g, "Carbohydrates (g)"= carb_g) my_better_pca <- prcomp(my_sub2, scale = TRUE) summary(my_better_pca) # cumulative proportion for 2 dimensions is 64% ## Importance of components: ## PC1 PC2 PC3 PC4 PC5 PC6 ## Standard deviation 1.5849 1.1611 0.9915 0.8351 0.67778 0.01245 ## Proportion of Variance 0.4186 0.2247 0.1638 0.1162 0.07656 0.00003 ## Cumulative Proportion 0.4186 0.6433 0.8072 0.9234 0.99997 1.00000 #plot(my_better_pca, xlab= "Dimensions") biplot(my_better_pca) my_better_biplot <- autoplot(my_better_pca, colour = NA, loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.colour= "black", loadings.label.size = 4, loadings.label.colour = "darkblue", loadings.label.repel = TRUE) + labs(x = "Principal Component 1 (41.86%)", y = "Principal Component 2 (22.47%)")+ theme_minimal() my_better_biplot Figure 2. Principle Component Analysis (PCA) biplot for nutritional information of cheese. Energy content is expressed in kilocalories whereas fat, carbohydrates, fiber, protein, sugar are expressed in grams. Principle Component 1 explains 41.86% and Principle Component 2 explains 22.7% of the variation in the data, resulting in the cumulative proportion of 64.33%. Energy content and fat had high negative loading scores on PC1 meaning high variance. Data used with permission from USDA.
 Part 3 : Summary of Major Takeaways  Energy content is highly correalted to the amount of fat. Carbohydrates are highly correlated to sugar. Carbohydrates and sugar are minimally correlated with fiber Energy content and fat are negatively correlated to fiber Energy and fat show the highest variation in the PC1 direction Cumulative proportion is 64% meaning 64 of the variance can be explained in 2 dimensions. Biplot shows that there are no clusters.
summary: Principal Component Analysis of Nutrional Information of Cheese
title: Principle Component Analysis

content:
Main objectives of this project are to examine the changes in the Steelhead Salmon (Oncorhynchus mykiss) passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon between the years 1940 and 2019, and to identify the seasonality and cyclycality of the passage if present. The data is provided by Columbia Basin Research [1] and it is analyzed to see whether there are seasonal patterns and/or bigger trends in salmon passage.
#read in the data salmon_data <- read_csv("cbr_fish.csv") %>% clean_names() #unique(salmon_data$location) #unique(salmon_data$parameter) #summary(salmon_data) # single location, single parameter # arrange dates salmon_date <- salmon_data %>% separate(mm_dd,into=c("day","month"),sep="-") %>% mutate(yy_mm_dd=ymd(paste(year,month,day)))%>% mutate(month_sep = yearmonth(yy_mm_dd)) %>% drop_na(month_sep) #plotting daily passage salmon_graph<-ggplot(data = salmon_date, aes(x = yy_mm_dd, y = value)) + geom_line(color='midnightblue') + theme_bw()+ labs(x = "Year", y = "Daily Steelhead Salmon Passage")+ theme(text = element_text(size=12))+ scale_x_date(date_breaks = "5 year", date_labels = "%Y", limit=c(as.Date("1939-12-31"),as.Date("2019-12-31")))+ theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=30, hjust=1)) salmon_graph Figure 2: Times series plot of daily Steelhead Salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam (1940-2019). The times series plots shows a seasonal pattern yearly. There might be a broader cyclical trend which needs further exploration. Data used with permission from Columbia Basin Research.
# group by year and month and find the total counts salmon_date2<- salmon_date %>% group_by(year, month) %>% summarise( value=sum(value, na.rm= TRUE)) #rename the columns salmon_date3<-salmon_date2 %>% rename("Year"=year) %>% rename("Month"=month) salmon_date3$Month = factor(salmon_date3$Month, levels = month.abb) options(scipen = 999) #getting rid of scientific notation ggplot(data = salmon_date3, aes(x = Month, y = value, group = Year)) + geom_line(aes(color = Year))+ theme_bw()+ labs(y="Monthly Total Count")+ scale_colour_gradient(low = "salmon1", high = "salmon4")+ theme(text = element_text(size=12)) Figure 3: Seasonplot of monthly total steelhead Salmon passage across the Bonneville Dam over the years. Colors indicate the years from 1940-2019 going from lighter to darker. The seasonplot shows that there is a seasonal pattern in salmon passage. It starts to increase around May-June, peaks around August every year. Data used with permission from Columbia Basin Research.
# use index by function and find annual sums salmon_annual <- salmon_ts %>% index_by(Year = ~year(.)) %>% summarize( total = sum(value,na.rm = TRUE) ) ggplot(data = salmon_annual, aes(x = Year, y = total)) + geom_line(color = "salmon4") + geom_smooth(color = "darkorchid4", size = 0.2, linetype = "dashed", fill = "darkorchid2", alpha = 0.1) + theme_bw()+ scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1940,2020, by = 5))+ labs(y="Annual Steelhead Salmon Passage")+ theme(axis.text.x=element_text(angle=30, hjust=1))+ theme(text = element_text(size=12)) Figure 4: Total Annual Steelhead Salmon Passage(1940-2019). Smoothed dashed lines are added to observe the overall trends over the years. It is unclear whether there is a broader cyclical trend in Steelhead Salmon passage. Likewise, it is hard to talk about a bigger general trend. Data used with permission from Columbia Basin Research.
REFERENCES
[1] : Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text
summary: Main objectives of this project are to examine the changes in the Steelhead Salmon (Oncorhynchus mykiss) passage across the Bonneville Dam in Oregon between the years 1940 and 2019, and to identify the seasonality and cyclycality of the passage if present. The data is provided by Columbia Basin Research [1] and it is analyzed to see whether there are seasonal patterns and/or bigger trends in salmon passage.
title: Time Series Data Analysis

content:
Maui is the second largest Hawaiian island with the surface area of 727.2 square miles [1]. This project aims to visualize the watersheds and main types of land covers on the island.
#reading in the data hawaii_land <- read_sf(dsn = ".", layer = "Land_Use_Land_Cover_LULC") %>% dplyr::select(landcover) %>% filter(!str_detect(landcover, pattern = "0")) #filtering for main land use types hawaii_land2<- hawaii_land %>% filter(landcover %in% c("Cropland and Pasture","Residential","Evergreen Forest Land", "Shrub and Brush Rangeland")) #unique(hawaii_land$landcover) hawaii_water <- read_sf(dsn = ".", layer = "Watersheds") # checking crs #st_crs(hawaii_land) #4326 #st_crs(hawaii_water) #4326 # grpahing watersheds and land use together ggplot(hawaii_land)+ geom_sf(color = "black", size = 0.1) + geom_sf(data = hawaii_land2, aes(fill = landcover), color = "NA") + scale_fill_manual(values=c("darkgoldenrod2","darkgreen","darkorchid4","palegreen3"),name="Land Cover")+ geom_sf(data = hawaii_water, color = "dodgerblue4", alpha = 0.3, size = 0.15, color = "NA") + coord_sf(datum = NA) + # Removes graticules geom_point(aes(x = -156.3319, y = 20.7984), size = 2)+ geom_text(x = -156.3319, y = 20.82, label = "Maui", size=7)+ coord_sf(xlim = c(-155.98,-156.68), ylim = c(20.45,21.1)) + theme_bw()+ labs(x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude")+ theme( legend.position = "right", legend.justification = c("right"), legend.box.just = "right", legend.margin = margin(3, 3, 3, 3), legend.text = element_text(size = 7) )+ annotation_scale(location = "br", width_hint = 0.5) + annotation_north_arrow(location = "br", which_north = "true", pad_x = unit(0.3, "in"), pad_y = unit(0.3, "in"), style = north_arrow_fancy_orienteering) Figure 2: Map of main land use types and the watersheds on the island of Maui. The most prominent land use types are Cropland and Pasture, Evergreen Forest Land, and Shrub and Brush Rangeland. Evergreen Forestland is mostly clustred around the watersheds. Data used with permission from Hawaii Statewide GIS Program.
REFERENCES
[1] : “Table 5.08 - Land Area of Islands: 2000”, 2004 State of Hawaii Data Book (PDF), State of Hawaii, 2004, retrieved 2007-07-23.
summary: This project aims to visualize the watersheds and main types of land covers on Maui island.
title: Spatial Data Analysis

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let's make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions? Ask
Documentation
summary: An introduction to using Academic's Slides feature.
title: Slides

content:
Sunday, August 11th - Kayonza, Rwanda
Written by: Professor Sangwon Suh & Ilayda Dinc of UCSB Bren School of Environmental Studies and Management
It was Sunday afternoon. We went to Kayonza district and met twenty representatives from four co-ops for the first demonstration of new high-efficiency cookstoves. Since our first day in Rwanda, we have been interviewing with the people in the cooperatives about their cooking method, fuel consumption, and cost. Those twenty representatives were the people we have already met a couple of days ago. As soon as we got there, we could tell from their eyes that they were happy to see us.
This is a project we have been working on since April, so we had an idea about the severity of the situation. According to our research, every year, 3.8 million people die prematurely from the use of inefficient cookstoves [1] Globally, as many as 3 billion people, mainly in rural Africa and Asia, are relying on inefficient cooking technologies such as three-stone wood fire and charcoal stoves for daily cooking needs [2]. The bystanders of these primitive stoves, mainly women and children, are exposed to a large quantity of hazardous substances equivalent to that from smoking 2 packs of cigarettes every day [3]. They also generate large quantities of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and accelerate deforestation.
But the things we witnessed were even more serious than we anticipated, partly because the communities that we visited were composed of underprivileged families and individuals even in Rwandan standard. We learned that most of the families that we visited spend almost half of their income on buying cooking fuels such as firewood and charcoal. They told us that they spend on average about 20,000 Rwandan Franc (RF) per month per household for cooking fuels such as firewood and charcoal. The efficiency of the conventional stoves that run on these fuels goes only about 5-10%, so much of the cooking fuels are wasted. The high-efficiency gasification cookstove that we demonstrated, however, reaches about 50% thermal efficiency. Also, some of them were experiencing respiratory problems such as coughing. So, our interviews and observations proved that efficient and cleaner cooking technology is urgently needed in Rwanda.
On the day of the demonstration, we were not entirely sure how receptive the co-op members would be. It was an important first test for us. We started to assemble the cookstoves while co-op members were watching us with curious eyes. After a couple, they started to help us and assemble the cookstoves themselves.
Then, we were ready to cook. We started to cook rice using a conventional three-stone fire stove and a Mimi Moto gasification stove side-by-side. The idea was to let the co-op members discover and experience the differences on their own so that they see the value of high-efficiency cookstove by themselves in the absence of our preaching. “What’s the difference that you see?” Sangwon asked.
The co-op members responded immediately. Multiple members pointed out that the three-stone fire stove was smoky while the high-efficiency gasification stove wasn’t. They also noticed that the flame from the three-stone stove wasn’t well contained, whereas that from the gasification stove was concentrated only to the center. The moment that we heard those two responses, we knew that these co-op members would readily adopt the new technology, and they indeed did.
From the beginning of the demonstration, they attentively watched and took notes on their notebooks. After we were done with cooking, they started to ask very thoughtful questions. One of them asked about what happens if water touches the circuit area. That question made us even happier because it was obvious that they want to take good care of their new cookstoves. Another one asked about the sustainability of wood pellet supply. This was very exciting to hear because in the long run, supply security of wood pellets should be addressed and they are already advancing their thoughts to the future. Hearing them coming up with these questions made us even more hopeful about the uptake of the new cooking technology.
Recognizing the benefits of the new cooking technology by themselves, by the end of the session, these co-op representatives became eager to enroll in our experimental program. Each participant of the program receives a cookstove, and, in return, they report to us the amount of fuel consumption before and after receiving the new cookstove. One of the co-op leaders, Eugene, volunteered to take the responsibility of collecting and reporting data for us.
By the end of the day, we were able to demonstrate the new cookstove, trained 20 co-op representatives, distributed our first batch of high-efficiency cookstoves, and successfully launched our data collection program.
And the best part? Seeing how happy the people are as they walk away with new cookstoves. These stoves will help save money and improve the health of their family members. As we approach the end of our trip, this day proved us it was only the beginning.
[1] “Global Health Observatory (GHO) data,” World Health Organization (WHO),https://www.who.int/gho/phe/indoor_air_pollution/burden/en/ [2] “Household air pollution and health,” WHO, https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/household-air-pollution-and-health [3] “Fuel for life: household energy and health,” WHO, https://www.who.int/airpollution/publications/fuelforlife.pdf?ua=1
 The text of this blog has been adapted from existing writings by Adopt a Cookstove team members and taken from World Dance for Humanity's Rwanda Travel blog. For more information and photos: https://wd4hrwandatripblog.wixsite.com/rwandatrips/post/day-12-cookstoves-in-kayonza
summary: Demonstration Day at Kayonza District, Rwanda
title: Adopt a Cookstove Project
